citation.article-title: Clostridium viride sp. nov., a strictly anaerobic bacterium using 5-aminovalerate as growth substrate, previously assigned to Clostridium aminovalericum.

p.s: Description of Clostridium viride sp. nov.
Clostridium viride (vi'ri.de. L. adj. viridis, e green, greenish; in reference to the green-colored cells and green FAD-containing enzymes of this organism)
The cells are gram-positive pointed-ended to oval rods, 0.8 μm wide and 1.2-1.5 μm long, and are motile by two subpolarly inserted flagella.
The center-to-center spacing of the hexagonally arranged S-layer lattice is 18.5 nm.
Cell pellets are yellowish-green in color.

Growth is supported by 5-aminovalerate (fermented to acetate, propionate, valerate, and ammonia), 5-hydroxyvalerate (fermented to acetate, propionate, and valerate), and crotonate, vinylacetate, and 4-hydroxybutyrate (fermented to acetate and butyrate).
No significant hydrogen production occurs on 5-aminovalerate.

The following substrates do not support growth (D-isomers of sugars and L-isomers of organic and amino acids were tested unless noted otherwise; substrates marked with an asterisk were also tested in the presence of 2 mM acetate): H2* (excess), glucose, fructose, galactose, ribose, xylose, arabinose, melibiose, mannose (all 4 mM), cellobiose, maltose, sucrose, lactose (all 2 mM), cellulose, starch, pectin (all at 1 g⋄l-1), formate*, pyruvate, lactate, succinate, malate, fumarate, glycerol*, mannitol, DL-3-hydroxybutyrate, tartrate, 1,2-propanediol* (all 20 mM), acrylate, citrate (both 10 mM), betaine, alanine, β-alanine, aspartate, norvaline, 2-aminobutyrate, 4-aminobutyrate, 6-aminocaproate, glutamate, isoleucine, arginine, proline, urea, valine (all 20 mM), leucine (15mM), tryptophan (5mM), trypticase, yeast extract, and casamino acids (all 1 g⋄l-1).
Nitrate, sulphate, amorphous ferric hydroxide, and fumarate are not used as electron acceptors.
Sulphur is reduced to sulphide at the expense of valerate production, but this is neither linked to energy conservation, nor does it stop reductive valerate formation.
5-Aminovalerate is metabolized via 2,4-pentadienoyl-CoA and 2-pentenoyl-CoA by a pathway involving at least two FAD-containing enzymes that form green crystals.
Strictly anaerobic conditions are required for growth.
Indole is not formed from L-tryptophan.
Urea, aesculin, and gelatin are not hydrolyzed.
Growth is possible at 40°C but not at 44°C Both yeast extract and L-cysteine are required for growth on 5-aminovalerate.
The G + C ratio of the DNA is 41.5 mol%.
16S rRNA analysis shows that strain T2-7 forms a distinct lineage within a phylogenetically coherent cluster of Clostridium spp. not related to Group I.
The type strain is T2-7 (DSM 6836), isolated from anaerobic sewage sludge.
